Comment: Ding-a-ling!  Time for Round 2 against Grundnorm in the Beafyness tourney.  I get a seemingly reasonable position as white but then a pawn push on the queenside pushes my pieces back and later on black has a decisive pawn majority which nets him a passed pawn.  I try to get my pieces to pile up on it but I do not get the chance to take it free of charge.  The position of the black rook and the Wicked Witch of the West provide the final denouement for me.  I decide to kick off with d4 as I played e4 against him in a recent unrated game and lost so I thought I would mix things up.
2. ....... Bf5 - an unusual 2nd move, but that bishop stays there until a few moves before the end with devastating effect as that will help to interfere with the co-ordination of my pieces.
2. ....... Bf5 - an unusual 2nd move, but that bishop stays there until a few moves before the end with devastating effect as that will help to interfere with the co-ordination of my pieces.

39. ........ Qf1 .  Glenda is obliged to block the Witch's check and desert the white rook on b5.  The Wicked Witch will turn him into mush next move so I wave the white flag.  A delightful lesson on how to convert a pawn majority into a victory - Joanne.
